entry.title: Book notes - Systems Engineering Toolbox for Design Oriented Engineers

link.title: Book notes - Systems Engineering Toolbox for Design Oriented Engineers

entry.content:
Chapter 1: Introduction

Definitions

  • A tool is defined as a set of procedures to accomplish a specific function.
  • A methodology is defined as a collection of tools, rules, and postulates to accomplish a purpose.

Types of tools

Tool Description
Concept development tools ... are useful when selecting the preferred option of several alternatives. Among these alternatives are such things as cost, complexity, weight, safety, manufacturability, or perhaps determining the ratio of expected future benefits to the expected future costs.
System safety and reliability tools ... address the following areas of concern: (1) identify and assess hazards, (2) identify failure modes and show their consequences or effects, and (3) symbolic logic modeling tools used to understand the failure mechanisms of the system. These tools are also used to determine the probability of failure occurring or the reliability that a component will operate successfully, either in comparative or absolute terms, as applicable.
Design-related analytical tools ... are applied to show (1) which parameters affect a system the most or least, (2) a method for specifying dimensions and tolerances, and (3) the determination of the possibility or probability of having form, fit, or function problems with a design, or to determine a tolerance or dimension necessary to avoid these problems.
Graphical data interpretation tools ... are applied when there is a desire to monitor performance, identify relationships, or reveal the most important variables in a set of data.
Statistical tools and methodologies ... compare sample statistics and population statistics. Variations are identified and mathematical relationships are determined.
Total quality management (TQM) tools ... are applied to continuously improve performance at all levels of operation, in all areas of an organization, using all available human and capital resources.
Quantitative tools ... that are used to identify potentially hazardous conditions based on past empirical data are trend analysis tools. The ultimate objective for these tools is to assess the current status, and to forecast future events.

Chapter 2: Concept Development Tools

Tool Description
Trade Studies Trade studies are used to quantitatively or qualitatively compare alternatives to select the most preferred one. They are categorized as either weighted factor trade studies, or its special version, the analytical hierarchy trade study. The former is performed when the options under consideration as well as program requirements are well defined, while the latter is used when comparing alternatives pairwise and when it is easier to generate preferences using subjective verbal expressions rather than numerical values.
Advantages: to be realized are (i) resources expended can be commensurate with the benefits of the task, (ii) technique can be adapted to prioritization based upon programmatic and technical considerations, (iii) identification of disadvantages of an option can lead to effective countermeasures, and (iv) the method provides a clearly documented analysis in which objectives and requirements, alternatives, and methodology are recorded.
Limitations: include (i) the technique depends on the analyst's expertise and amount of available data, (ii) the assessment can be prejudiced and result in incorrect results if inappropriate selection criteria, weights, and utility functions are used, (iii) the number of alternatives considered are limited by amount of analysis resources, (iv) the options to be evaluated must be determined prior to analysis, and (v) the weighting factors and advantages/disadvantages are subjective.
Cost-Versus-Benefit Studies Trade studies are used to quantitatively or qualitatively compare alternatives to select the most preferred one. They are categorized as either weighted factor trade studies, or its special version, the analytical hierarchy trade study. The former is performed when the options under consideration as well as program requirements are well defined, while the latter is used when comparing alternatives pairwise and when it is easier to generate preferences using subjective verbal expressions rather than numerical values. These are typically done early in the project, though they can be done whenever a method is needed to select alternatives. A trade study analysis allows a systematic approach to evaluation of design options and may also help delineate the most important system requirements.
Advantages: to be realized are (i) the analyst can assess the cost effectiveness of several alternatives over the entire life cycle, and (ii) the method provides a clearly documented analysis in which objectives and requirements, alternatives, and methodology are recorded.
Limitations: include (i) the analysis is flawed if system requirements are incomplete or inadequate - the costs can be underestimated if the operating environment is not well understood or characterized and benefits cannot be well addressed if requirements are too vague or general, (ii) an incomplete list of alternatives leads to incomplete analysis, (iii) the analysis is flawed if incomplete or inaccurate cost estimates are used, (iv) the benefits must be quantified even if they are intangible, insubstantial, or difficult to state in monetary terms, and (v) the method does not take into account technical factors besides cost, so this tool is generally insufficient for selection of large, new design efforts, but more appropriate to production-level design solutions..

Chapter 3: System Safety and Reliability Tools

Tool Description
Trade Studies Trade studies are used to quantitatively or qualitatively compare alternatives to select the most preferred one. They are categorized as either weighted factor trade studies, or its special version, the analytical hierarchy trade study. The former is performed when the options under consideration as well as program requirements are well defined, while the latter is used when comparing alternatives pairwise and when it is easier to generate preferences using subjective verbal expressions rather than numerical values.
Advantages
Limitations
Cost-Versus-Benefit Studies Trade studies are used to quantitatively or qualitatively compare alternatives to select the most preferred one. They are categorized as either weighted factor trade studies, or its special version, the analytical hierarchy trade study. The former is performed when the options under consideration as well as program requirements are well defined, while the latter is used when comparing alternatives pairwise and when it is easier to generate preferences using subjective verbal expressions rather than numerical values.
Advantages
Limitations

Update in progress ...
entry.summary: These are notes I made when reading the the book by Goldberg et al. (1994)

entry.title: Selected Papers on Optimization, Design, and Control Systems

link.title: Selected Papers on Optimization, Design, and Control Systems

entry.content:
An assortment of some excellent papers I have read over the years

Updated: March 2018

On Dynamics and Control

• Ljung, Lennart. “Perspectives on System Identification.” Annual Reviews in Control 34, no. 1 (April 2010): 1–12. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.arcontrol.2009.12.001.

• Neculai, Andrei. “Modern Control Theory. A Historical Perspective.” Romania: Research Institute for Informatics, 2005.

• Vamvoudakis, Kyriakos G., Panos J. Antsaklis, Warren E. Dixon, Joao P. Hespanha, Frank L. Lewis, Hamidreza Modares, and Bahare Kiumarsi. “Autonomy and Machine Intelligence in Complex Systems: A Tutorial.” In 2015 American Control Conference (ACC), 5062–79. Chicago, IL, USA: IEEE, 2015. https://doi.org/10.1109/ACC.2015.7172127.

On Math and Optimization

• Jones, Donald R. “A Taxonomy of Global Optimization Methods Based on Response Surfaces.” Journal of Global Optimization 21, no. 4 (December 2001): 345–83. https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1012771025575.

• Martins, Joaquim R. R. A., and Andrew B. Lambe. “Multidisciplinary Design Optimization: A Survey of Architectures.” AIAA Journal 51, no. 9 (September 2013): 2049–75. https://doi.org/10.2514/1.J051895.

• Powell, Warren B. “What You Should Know about Approximate Dynamic Programming.” Naval Research Logistics 56, no. 3 (April 2009): 239–49. https://doi.org/10.1002/nav.20347.

• Powell, Warren B. "A unified framework for stochastic optimization." European Journal of Operational Research, Volume 275, Issue 3, (June 2019): 795-821.

• Viana, Felipe A. C., Timothy W. Simpson, Vladimir Balabanov, and Vasilli Toropov. “Special Section on Multidisciplinary Design Optimization: Metamodeling in Multidisciplinary Design Optimization: How Far Have We Really Come?” AIAA Journal 52, no. 4 (April 2014): 670–90. https://doi.org/10.2514/1.J052375.
entry.summary: An assortment of some excellent papers I have read over the years.

entry.title: List of books I have read

link.title: List of books I have read

entry.content:
Books I have read over the years

Updated: April 2019

I started keeping track of all books I have read since 2015. This is the entire list, in reverse chronological order.

2019

  • White, E. B. Charlotte's Web. Harper and Row, 1980.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The Truth. (Discworld #25, Industrial Revolution #2) Harper, 2000.
  • Sandlas, V. P. The Leapfroggers: An Insider's Account of ISRO. HarperCollins, 2018.
  • Aravamudan, R., and Gita Aravamudan. ISRO: A Personal History. HarperCollins, 2017.
  • Pratchett, Terry. Moving Pictures. (Discworld #10, Industrial Revolution #1) Harper, 2002.
  • Dennis Jr., Daniel J. Gems: A Lively Guide for the Casual Collector. Harry N. Abrams, 1999.

2018

  • Aaronson, Scott. Quantum computing since Democritus. Cambridge University Press, 2013.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The Shepherd's Crown. (Discworld #41, Tiffany Aching #5) Doubleday, 2015.
  • Vonnegut, Kurt. Cat's Cradle. Dial Press, 1998.
  • Pratchett, Terry. I Shall Wear Midnight. (Discworld #38, Tiffany Aching #4) Doubleday, 2010.
  • Merlin, Peter W. From Archangel to Senior Crown: Design and Development of the Blackbird. American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics, 2008.
  • Bercovici, Jeff. Play on: The New Science of Elite Performance at Any Age. Penguin Books, 2018.
  • Pratchett, Terry. Wintersmith. (Discworld #35, Tiffany Aching #3) Doubleday, 2006.
  • Harari, Yuval Noah. Sapiens: A brief history of humankind. Random House, 2014.
  • Pratchett, Terry. A Hat Full of Sky. (Discworld #32, Tiffany Aching #2) Doubleday, 2004.
  • Clancy, Tom. The hunt for red October. Penguin, 1985.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The Wee Free Men. (Discworld #30, Tiffany Aching #1) Doubleday, 2003.
  • Harari, Yuval Noah. Homo Deus: A brief history of tomorrow. Random House, 2016.
  • Munroe, Randall. What If?: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions. Hachette UK, 2014.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The Amazing Maurice and His Educated Rodents. (Discworld #28) Doubleday, 2001.

2017

  • Pratchett, Terry. Unseen Academicals. (Discworld #37, Rincewind #8) Doubleday, 2009.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The last hero. (Discworld #27, Rincewind #7) Victor Gollancz, 2001.
  • Wells, Herbert George. The First Men in the Moon. Magnum, 1968.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The last continent. (Discworld #22, Rincewind #6) Doubleday, 1998.
  • Pratchett, Terry. Interesting times. (Discworld #17, Rincewind #5) Victor Gollancz, 1994.
  • Pratchett, Terry, and Josh Kirby. Eric. (Discworld #9, Rincewind #4) Corgy, 1990.
  • Schwab, Klaus. The fourth industrial revolution. Crown Business, 2017.
  • Pratchett, Terry. Sourcery. (Discworld #5, Rincewind #3) Colin Smythe, 1988.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The Light Fantastic. (Discworld #2, Rincewind #2) Colin Smythe, 1986.
  • Pratchett, Terry. The colour of magic. (Discworld #1, Rincewind #1) Colin Smythe, 1983.
  • Gaiman, Neil. Norse mythology. WW Norton & Company, 2017.
  • Clark, John Drury. Ignition!: An informal history of liquid rocket propellants. Rutgers University Press, 1972.
  • Christie, Agatha. And then there were none. Macmillan, 2004.
  • Nordgren, Tyler. Sun Moon Earth: The History of Solar Eclipses from Omens of Doom to Einstein and Exoplanets. Basic Books, 2016.
  • Loftis, Larry. Into the Lion's Mouth: The True Story of Dusko Popov: World War II Spy, Patriot, and the Real-Life Inspiration for James Bond. Penguin, 2016.
  • Heller, Joseph. Catch-22: a novel. Vol. 4. Simon and Schuster, 1999.

2016

  • Rovelli, Carlo. Seven brief lessons on physics. Riverhead Books (Hardcover), 2016.
  • Stanley, Thomas J., and William D. Danko. The Millionaire Next Door: The Surprising Secrets of America’s Wealthy. Longstreet Press, 1996.
  • Eckert, Carolyn. Your idea starts here: 77 mind-expanding ways to unleash your creativity. Storey Publishing, 2016.
  • Kiyosaki, Robert T., John Fleming, and Kim Kiyosaki. The Business of the 21st century. DreamBuilders, 2010.
  • Johnson, Clarence L. Kelly: more than my share of it all. Smithsonian Institution, 2012.
  • Singh, Simon. Big Bang: The origin of the universe. Harper Perennial, 2004.
  • Pratchett, Terry, and Neil Gaiman. Good Omens: The nice and accurate prophecies of Agnes Nutter, witch. Random House, 2011.
  • Marshall, Tim. Prisoners of geography: Ten maps that tell you everything you need to know about global politics. Elliot and Thompson, 2015.
  • Bradbury, Ray. The martian chronicles. Simon and Schuster, 2012.
  • Goscinny, Rene, and Albert Uderzo. Asterix the Gladiator. Asterix #4.
  • Ferri, Jean-Yves, Didier Conrad and Anthea Bell. Asterix and the Picts. Asterix #35.
  • Carroll, Lewis. Alice's adventures in wonderland. Broadview Press, 2011.

2015

  • Sutter, Joe and Jay Spenser. 747: Creating the World's first Jumbo Jet and other adventures from a life in aviation. HarperCollinsPublishers, 2006.
  • Gonick, Larry, and Woollcott Smith. The cartoon guide to statistics. New York: HarperPerennial, 1993.
  • Anderson Jr., John David. The airplane, a history of its technology. AIAA, 2002.
  • Brosh, Alexandra. Hyperbole and a half: Unfortunate situations, flawed coping mechanisms, mayhem, and other things that happened. Random House, 2013.
  • Miodownik, Mark. Stuff Matters: Exploring the Marvelous Materials that Shape Our Man-made World. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2014.
  • Yeager, Chuck, and Leo Janos. Yeager: An Autobiography. Toronto: Bantam Books, 1985.
  • Padua, Sydney. The Thrilling Adventures of Lovelace and Babbage: the (mostly) true story of the first computer. Penguin UK, 2015.
  • Aurelius, Marcus. Meditations. Oxford University Press, 2013.
  • Lansing, Alfred. Endurance: Shackleton's Incredible Voyage. Basic Books (AZ), 2014.
  • Poundstone, William. Are You Smart Enough to Work at Google? Oneworld Publication, 2013.
  • Gardner, Martin. Hexaflexagons, Probability Paradoxes, and the Tower of Hanoi: Martin Gardner's First Book of Mathematical Puzzles and Games. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2008.
  • Hadfield, Chris. An Astronaut's Guide to Life on Earth. 2013.
  • Saint-Exupéry, Antoine, and Katherine Woods. The Little Prince. New York: Harcourt, Brace & World, 1943.
  • Navarro, Joe, and Marvin Karlins. What Every Body Is Saying: An Ex-Fbi Agent's Guide to Speed Reading People. New York, NY: Collins, 2008.
  • Hawkins, Jeff, and Sandra Blakeslee. On intelligence: How a new understanding of the brain will lead to the creation of truly intelligent machines. Macmillan, 2007.
entry.summary: I keep track of books that I read; this is the list of all of them.
